abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory on
            balance. The sustainability of project activities and
            achievements is likely (except in Maluku), but not
            assured.Overall, both World Bank and Borrower performances
            are rated as satisfactory. The project provided specific
            lessons related to iodine deficiency disease (IDD) and
            midwives: The national IDD strategy should differentiate
            responses according to local situations. It is essential to
            recognize the role of private sector producers, wholesalers,
            and retailers in the salt industry and the importance of
            improving efficiency in salt production and processing.
            Updated information is needed on both the IDD status of the
            population in different regions and the iodine content of
            salt consumed at the household level. The government's
            midwives initiatives need to address both supply and demand
            factors, and to be locally grounded and focused. Upgrading
            the skills of midwives requires strengthening of
            pre-services as well as in-service training. Improving
            effectiveness will also require intensified supervision and
            support, directed especially at the more recent graduates.
            The village midwife's role needs to be widened to a
            number of other community level health services. Lessons of
            broader applicability pertain to: the complexity of project
            design, matching the project objective with government
            capacity, the need for government commitment, developing a
            strategy that responds to local conditions, and
            disseminating study results.
